bestBHT.bht: The ship struggled to pass by the Fair Havens due to the westerly current and head winds, and they had to coast along it with great difficulty. Fair Havens, a small bay near Cape Matala, was the suitable anchorage for the ship. Although the city of Lasea near Fair Havens is lost, it was once well-known and mentioned by ancient writers. This incident supports the Bible's geographical accuracy, as confirmed by the discovery of a Scottish yachting party.

Henry Alford: The Sidonians were renowned for their manufactures of glass, linen, silversmith’s work, and for the hewing of timber.

The refreshing himself (literally, getting attention paid him) was perhaps to obtain from them that outfit for the voyage which, on account of the official precision of his custody at Cæsarea, he could not there be provided with.
The most conclusive evidence that this is the Fair Havens of Scripture, is, that its position is precisely that where a ship circumstanced as St. Paul’s was must have put in.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: hardly passing it—"with difficulty coasting along it," from the same cause as before, the westerly current and head winds.
came to . . . the Fair Havens—an anchorage near the center of the south coast, and a little east of Cape Matala, the southern most point of the island.
nigh whereunto was the city Lasea—identified by the REVEREND GEORGE BROWN [SMITH, Voyages and Shipwreck of St. Paul, Appendix 3, Second Edition, 1856].
Albert Barnes: Scarcely being able to pass by it without being wrecked.
It was probably not so much a harbor as an open roadstead, which afforded good anchorage for a time.
There was no town or city at the 'Fair Havens,' but the city of Lasea seems to have been well known.
Philip Schaff: It seems that they were hardly able to accomplish their purpose: but they did accomplish it.
The direct course of a ship on her voyage from Myra to Italy, after she had reached Cnidus, is by the north side of Crete, through the Archipelago, west by south.
This curious discovery of a Scotch yachting party may be classed among the really valuable geographical evidences of the truth of the Bible.
Archibald T. Robertson: Coasting along, like Latin legere oram."
Fair Havens, a small bay two miles east of Cape Matala."
Neither Lasea nor Fair Havens is mentioned by any ancient writer.
John Gill: And hardly passing it,.... That is, Salmone, with great difficulty, because of the winds
called by other writers Cale Acte, or the fair shore
Jerom says, Lasea is a city on the shore of the island of Crete, near the place which is called the Fair Havens, as Luke himself explains it
John Wesley: The Fair Havens still retain the name.
The city of Lasea is now utterly lost.
Together with many more of the hundred cities for which Crete was once so renowned.

bhtAttempts.bht: The ship St. Paul was on had a challenging time passing by the Fair Havens due to the westerly current and head winds. Fair Havens itself was a small bay near the center of the south coast of Crete, and its positioning made it an ideal stopping point for ships facing difficulties. Although the city of Lasea, which was near Fair Havens, is now lost, it was once well-known and mentioned by several ancient writers. The journey through the Archipelago, west by south, was not an easy one, but with great difficulty, the ship managed to continue its voyage. This incident demonstrated the fulfillment of geographical evidence from the Bible, as discovered by a Scottish yachting party.
